1.verse: Jerusalem Cries over Her Loss - How lonely sits the city [Jerusalem], once so full of people. She is like a widow, once great among the nations [Ps. 122:3]. She was like a queen ·of all the other cities [among the provinces], but now she is a ·slave [forced laborer; vassal].

2.verse: She [Jerusalem pictured as a widow] cries loudly at night, and tears are on her cheeks. There is no one to comfort her; ·all who loved her are gone [among all her lovers; referring to other nations to whom she unfaithfully turned for help]. All her friends have ·turned against [betrayed] her and are now her enemies.

3.verse: Judah has gone into ·captivity [exile; to Babylon; 2 Kin. 25:8–21; 2 Chr. 36:17–21; Jer. 39:1–10; 51:12–30] where she ·suffers [is oppressed/afflicted] ·and works hard [under slavery/harsh servitude]. She lives among other nations, but she has found no rest. Those who ·chased [pursued; persecuted] her caught her ·when she was in trouble [between her distresses].

4.verse: The roads to ·Jerusalem [Zion; the location of the Temple] ·are sad [mourn], because no one comes for the feasts [Passover, Pentecost, Tabernacles]. ·No one passes through her gates [All her gates are desolate]. Her priests groan, her young women are ·suffering [afflicted], and ·Jerusalem suffers terribly [she is bitter].

5.verse: Her foes are now her masters. Her enemies ·enjoy the wealth they have taken [prosper]. The LORD is ·punishing [tormenting; afflicting] her for her many ·sins [transgressions]. Her ·children [little ones] have gone away as captives of the ·enemy [foe].

6.verse: The ·beauty [splendor; majesty] of ·Jerusalem [the daughter of Zion; the location of the Temple; Ps. 48:1–3] has gone away. Her rulers are like deer that cannot find ·food [pasture]. They ·are weak [go without strength] ·and run from the hunters [before those who pursue/chase/persecute them].

7.verse: Jerusalem ·is suffering and homeless. She […in the days of her affliction and homelessness] remembers all the ·good [desirable; coveted] things from the ·past [former days]. But her people ·were defeated by the enemy [fell to the power/hand of the foe], and there was no one to help her. When her ·enemies [foes] saw her, they laughed ·to see her ruined [at her downfall].

8.verse: Jerusalem sinned terribly, so she has become ·unclean [or an object of mockery]. Those who honored her now ·hate [despise] her, because they have seen her nakedness. She groans and turns away.

9.verse: She made herself ·dirty [defiled] ·by her sins [in her skirts; Jerusalem is pictured as a defiled woman; Lev. 15:19–30] and did not think about what would happen to her. Her ·defeat [downfall] was surprising, and no one could comfort her. She says, “LORD, see how I ·suffer [am afflicted], because the enemy has won.”

10.verse: The ·enemy [foe] ·reached out and took [spread his hands on] all her ·precious [desired; coveted] things. She even saw ·foreigners [nations] enter her ·Temple [holy place; Ps. 74:4–8]. ·The LORD had commanded foreigners […those you commanded] never to enter the meeting place of ·his [your] people.

11.verse: All of ·Jerusalem’s [its] people groan, ·looking for [seeking] bread. They ·are trading [give] their ·precious [desired; coveted] things for food so they can stay alive. The city says, “Look, LORD, and see. I am ·hated [despised].”

12.verse: Jerusalem says, “You who pass by on the road ·don’t seem to care [is it nothing to you…?; No, to you]. Come, look at me and see: Is there any ·pain [sorrow] like ·mine [my pain/sorrow]? ·Is there any pain like that he has caused me […which has come upon me]? The LORD has ·punished [afflicted; tormented] me on the day of his great anger.

13.verse: “He sent fire from above that went ·down [deep] into my bones. He ·stretched [spread] out a net for my feet and turned me back. He made me so ·sad and lonely [desolate] that I am ·weak [faint; sick] all day.

14.verse: “He ·has noticed my sins [or bound my transgressions into a yoke]; they are ·tied together [intertwined] by his hands; they hang around my neck. ·He has turned my strength into weakness [My strength falters]. The Lord has handed me over to those who ·are stronger than I [I cannot stand against].

15.verse: “The Lord has rejected all my mighty men ·inside my walls [in my midst]. He ·brought an army [or proclaimed a time] against me to ·destroy [break] my young men. As if in a winepress, the Lord has ·crushed [trampled] the ·capital city [virgin daughter] of Judah [Is. 63:1–6].

16.verse: “I cry about these things; my eyes overflow with tears. ·There is no one near to comfort me [A comforter is far from me], no one who can ·give me strength again [restore my soul]. My children are ·left sad and lonely [desolate], because the enemy has ·won [prevailed].”

17.verse: ·Jerusalem [Zion; the location of the Temple] ·reaches [spreads] out her hands, but there is no one to comfort her. The LORD commanded the people of Jacob to be surrounded by their ·enemies [foes]. Jerusalem is now unclean [1:8–9] ·like [among] those around her.

18.verse: Jerusalem says, “The LORD is ·right [righteous], but I ·refused to obey him [have rebelled against his mouth]. Listen, all you people, and look at my ·pain [sorrow]. My young women and men have gone into captivity [1:3].

19.verse: “I called out to my ·friends [lovers; 1:2], but they ·turned against [deceived] me. My priests and my elders have died in the city while ·looking for [seeking] food to ·stay alive [revive their strength].

20.verse: “Look at me, LORD. I am ·upset [distressed] and ·greatly troubled [my innards/stomach/bowels are agitated]. My heart is ·troubled [overturned within me], because I have been so ·stubborn [rebellious]. Out in the streets, the sword ·kills [bereaves]; inside the houses, ·death destroys [it is like death].

21.verse: “People have heard my groaning, and there is no one to comfort me. All my enemies have heard of my trouble, and they are happy you have done this to me. Now bring that day you have announced so that ·my enemies [they] will be like me.

22.verse: “·Look at all their evil [Let all their evil come before you]. Do to them what you have done to me because of all my ·sins [transgressions]. I groan over and over again, and ·I am afraid [my heart is sick/faint/weak].”

1.verse: The Lord Destroyed Jerusalem - Look how the Lord in his anger has ·brought Jerusalem to shame [treated the daughter of Zion with contempt; or brought a cloud over the daughter of Zion]. He has thrown down the ·greatness [splendor; beauty] of Israel from the ·sky [heavens] to the earth; he did not remember his footstool [the Temple; Ps. 99:5; 132:7], on the day of his anger.

2.verse: The Lord swallowed up without ·mercy [pity] all the ·houses [homes; dwellings] of the people of Jacob; in his anger he ·pulled down [demolished] the strong places of [the daughter of] Judah. He threw her kingdom and its rulers down to the ground in dishonor.

3.verse: In his anger he has ·removed [cut to pieces] all the ·strength [horn; a symbol of pride and power] of Israel; he took away his ·power [right hand] from Israel when the enemy came. He burned against the people of Jacob [another name for Israel] like a flaming fire that burns up everything around it.

4.verse: Like an enemy, he ·prepared to shoot [bent; drew] his bow, and his right hand was against us [Ps. 7:12–13]. Like an ·enemy [foe], he killed all ·the good-looking people [which eye desired]; he poured out his anger like fire on the tents of ·Jerusalem [the daughter of Zion; the location of the Temple].

5.verse: The Lord was like an enemy; he swallowed up Israel. He swallowed up all her palaces and destroyed all her strongholds. He has ·caused more [multiplied] moaning and groaning for ·Judah [the daughter of Judah].

6.verse: He ·cut down [laid waste to; violently treated] his ·Temple [booth] like a ·garden [vineyard]; he destroyed the meeting place. The LORD has made ·Jerusalem [Zion; the location of the Temple] forget the ·set feasts [or meeting place] and Sabbath days. He has ·rejected [despised] the king and the priest in his great anger.

7.verse: The LORD has rejected his altar and ·abandoned [disavowed] his ·Temple [Holy Place; Ezek. 9–11]. He has ·handed over to [delivered into the hand of] the enemy the walls of its [probably Jerusalem’s] palaces. ·Their uproar [They gave forth voice] in the LORD’s ·Temple [house] was like that of a feast day.

8.verse: The LORD planned to destroy the wall around ·Jerusalem [the daughter of Zion; the location of the Temple]. He ·measured the wall [extended a measuring line; usually used in construction but here in demolition] and did not stop himself from ·destroying [swallowing] it. He made the walls and ·defenses [ramparts] ·sad [mourn]; together they have ·fallen [languished].

9.verse: ·Jerusalem’s [Its] gates have ·fallen [sunk] to the ground; he destroyed and smashed the bars [of the gates; Ps. 107:16; Is. 45:2; Jer. 51:30; Nah. 3:13]. Her king and her princes are among the nations. The ·teaching [law; instruction; God’s law] has stopped, and the prophets do not have visions from the LORD.

10.verse: The elders of ·Jerusalem [the daughter of Zion; the location of the Temple] sit on the ground in silence. They throw dust on their heads and put on ·rough cloth [sackcloth; burlap; signs of grief or repentance]. The young women of Jerusalem bow their heads to the ground [in sorrow].

11.verse: My eyes ·have no more tears [are exhausted from tears], and ·I am sick to my stomach [my innards/stomach/bowels are agitated]. ·I feel empty inside [My bile/gall is poured out on the ground], because ·my people [the daughter of my people] have been ·destroyed [shattered; broken]. Children and ·babies [nurslings] are fainting in the ·streets [public areas] of the city.

12.verse: They ask their mothers, “Where is the grain and wine?” They faint like wounded soldiers in the ·streets [public areas] of the city and ·die [pour out their lives] in their mothers’ ·arms [bosom].

13.verse: What can I ·say [testify] about you, [daughter] Jerusalem? What can I compare you to? What can I say you are like? How can I comfort you, ·Jerusalem [virgin daughter Zion; location of the Temple]? Your ·ruin [wound] is as ·deep [great] as the sea. ·No one [Who…?] can heal you.

14.verse: Your prophets saw visions, but they were ·false [empty] and ·worth nothing [insipid; nonsense; Ezek. 10:10–12]. They did not ·point out [expose] your ·sins [guilt] to ·keep you from being captured [or restore your fortunes]. They ·preached what was [saw oracles for you that were] ·false [empty] and ·led you wrongly [fraudulent].

15.verse: All who pass by on the road clap their hands at you [in approval of Jerusalem’s destruction; Ezek. 25:6]; they ·make fun of [hiss at; in scorn; 1 Kin. 9:8; Jer. 19:8; Zeph. 2:15] [the daughter of] Jerusalem and shake their heads. They ask, “Is this the city that people called the most beautiful city, the ·happiest place on [joy of the whole] earth [Ps. 48:2]?”

16.verse: All your enemies ·open [crack] their mouths to speak against you. They make fun and ·grind [gnash] their teeth [in anger]. They say, “We have swallowed you up. This is the day we were ·waiting [hoping] for! We have finally seen it happen.”

17.verse: The LORD has done what he planned; he has ·kept [fulfilled] his ·word [threat; the covenant curses; Deut. 28:45–50] that he commanded ·long ago [in days of old]. He has ·destroyed [demolished] without ·mercy [pity], and he has let your enemies laugh at you [such as Edom; Obad. 1–21]. He has ·strengthened [exalted the horn of; symbol of pride and power] your enemies.

18.verse: ·The people [Their hearts] cry out to the Lord. Wall of ·Jerusalem [the daughter of Zion; the location of the Temple], let your tears flow like a ·river [torrent; wadi] day and night. Do not ·stop [allow yourself relaxation] or let your eyes rest.

19.verse: Get up, cry out in the night, ·even as the night begins [at the beginning of the night watches; the night was divided into three four-hour watches]. Pour out your heart like water ·in prayer to [before the presence/face of] the Lord. Lift up your hands in prayer to him for the life of your children who are ·fainting [growing weak] with hunger ·on every street corner [at the head of every street].

20.verse: Jerusalem says: “Look, LORD, and see to whom you have done this. ·Women [Should women…?] eat their own ·babies [fruit; short for “fruit of their womb”], the children ·they have cared for [they have nursed/borne; or which are well-formed; Deut. 28:53–55; Jer. 19:6–9]. ·Priests and prophets are [Should priests and prophets be…?] killed in the ·Temple [holy place] of the Lord.

21.verse: “People young and old lie outside on the ground. My young women and young men have ·been killed [fallen] by the sword. You killed them on the day of your anger; you ·killed [slaughtered] them without ·mercy [pity].

22.verse: “You invited ·terrors [or enemies] to come against me on every side, as if ·you were inviting them to a feast [on an appointed/feast day]. No one escaped or remained alive on the day of the LORD’s anger. My enemy has ·killed [annihilated] those I ·cared for [nursed; bore] and brought up.”

1.verse: The Meaning of Suffering - I am a man [symbolizing Jerusalem] who has seen the ·suffering [affliction] that comes from the rod of ·the LORD’s [his] anger.

2.verse: He ·led [guided and brought] me into darkness, not light.

3.verse: He turned his hand against me again and again, all day long [Jer. 21:5].

4.verse: He ·wore out [wasted away] my flesh and skin and broke my bones.

5.verse: He ·surrounded me with sadness and attacked me with grief [has built up and besieged me with bitterness/or poverty and hardship].

6.verse: He made me sit in the dark, like those who have been dead a long time.

7.verse: He ·shut me [walled me] in so I could not get out; he put heavy chains on me.

8.verse: I cry out and beg for help, but he ·ignores [obstructs] my prayer.

9.verse: He ·blocked [walled in] my way with ·a stone wall [cut stones] and ·led me in the wrong direction [twisted my paths; Job 19:7–12].

10.verse: He is like a bear ready to ·attack [ambush] me, like a lion in hiding [Hos. 13:8; Amos 5:19].

11.verse: He led me the wrong way and ·let me stray [or tore me to pieces] and left me ·without help [desolate].

12.verse: He ·prepared to shoot [has drawn] his bow and made me the target for his arrows.

13.verse: He shot me in the kidneys with the arrows from his ·bag [quiver; Job 16:13].

14.verse: I was a joke to all my people, who make fun of me with ·songs [mocking songs] all day long [Ps. 22:7; 69:12; 119:51].

15.verse: ·The LORD [He] filled me with ·misery [bitterness]; he made me drunk with ·suffering [affliction; wormwood; gall; a bitter-tasting herb].

16.verse: He ·broke [made me gnash] my teeth with gravel and trampled me into the ·dirt [dust; ashes].

17.verse: ·I have no more peace [My life/soul is rejected from peace]. I have forgotten ·what happiness is [prosperity; good].

18.verse: I said, “My ·strength [luster; or endurance] ·is gone [has perished], and I have no hope in the LORD.”

19.verse: LORD, remember my ·suffering [affliction] and my ·misery [or wanderings; homelessness; 1:7], ·my sorrow and trouble [it is wormwood and gall; 3:15].

20.verse: Please remember me and think about ·me [my life].

21.verse: But I have hope when I ·think of this [return to my mind/heart]:

22.verse: The LORD’s ·love [loyalty] never ends; his ·mercies [compassion] never stop.

23.verse: They are new every morning; LORD, your ·loyalty [faithfulness] is ·great [abundant; Ps. 33:4; 92:2; 143:1].

24.verse: I say to myself, “The LORD is ·mine [my lot/portion], so I hope in him.”

25.verse: The LORD is good to those who ·hope in [wait for] him, to those who seek him.

26.verse: It is good to wait ·quietly [silently] for the LORD to ·save [be victorious].

27.verse: It is good for someone to ·work hard [carry/bear the yoke] while he is young.

28.verse: He should sit alone and be ·quiet [silent]; ·the LORD has given him hard work to do [when it is imposed/heavy on him].

29.verse: He should ·bow down to the ground [put his mouth in the dust]; maybe there is still hope.

30.verse: He should ·let anyone slap [give to the striker] his cheek; he should be ·filled [sated] with ·shame [scorn].

31.verse: The LORD will not reject his people forever.

32.verse: Although he brings ·sorrow [grief], he also has ·mercy [compassion] and great ·love [loyalty].

33.verse: He does not ·like to punish people [afflict from his heart] or make them ·sad [grieve].

34.verse: ·He sees [Does he not see…?] if any prisoner of the earth is crushed under ·his [or their; the wicked oppressors’] feet;

35.verse: ·he sees [does he not see…?] if ·someone is treated unfairly [human rights are distorted] before the Most High God;

36.verse: ·the LORD sees [does the Lord not see…?] if someone is cheated in his case in court.

37.verse: ·Nobody [Who…?] can speak and have it happen unless the Lord commands it.

38.verse: ·Both [Do not…?] bad and good things come by the command of the Most High God [Job 2:10].

39.verse: No ·one [living person] should complain ·when he is punished for [before] his sins.

40.verse: Let us ·examine [check] and ·see [investigate] ·what we have done [our ways] and then return to the LORD [repent; Jer. 17:9–10; Ps. 139:23–24].

41.verse: Let us lift up our hands ·and pray from [as well as] our hearts to God in heaven:

42.verse: “We have ·sinned [transgressed] and ·turned [rebelled] against you, and you have not forgiven us.

43.verse: “You ·wrapped [covered] yourself in anger and ·chased [pursued] us; you killed us without ·mercy [pity].

44.verse: You ·wrapped [covered] yourself in a cloud [Ex. 40:34–38], and no prayer could ·get [pass] through.

45.verse: You made us like ·scum [sweepings] and trash ·among the other nations [in the midst of the peoples].

46.verse: “All of our enemies ·open [crack] their mouths and speak against us [2:16].

47.verse: We have been ·frightened [terrified] and fearful, ruined and ·destroyed [broken].”

48.verse: ·Streams of tears [Channels of water] flow from my eyes, because ·my people are destroyed [of the fracture of my people].

49.verse: My tears flow ·continually [without ceasing], without ·stopping [respite; relaxation],

50.verse: until the LORD looks down and sees from heaven.

51.verse: ·I am sad when I see [My eyes torment my life/soul] ·what has happened to all the women [because of all the daughters] of my city.

52.verse: Those who are my enemies ·for no reason [without cause; Ps. 7:4; 35:7] hunted me like a bird [Ps. 91:3; Prov. 6:5; 7:23].

53.verse: They ·tried to kill me [destroyed my life/soul] in a pit [Ps. 7:15; 9:15]; they threw stones at me.

54.verse: Water came up over my head [Ps. 69:1–2], and I said, “I am ·going to die [lost; cut off].”

55.verse: I called out ·to you [your name], LORD, from the ·bottom [depth] of the pit [Ps. 130:1].

56.verse: You heard ·me calling [my voice], “Do not close your ears ·and ignore my gasps and shouts [to my cries for relief].”

57.verse: You came near ·when [in the day] I called to you; you said, “Don’t be afraid.”

58.verse: Lord, ·you have taken my case [you defend/have defended me] and ·given me back [redeem; redeemed] my life.

59.verse: LORD, you have seen how I have been wronged. Now judge my case for me.

60.verse: You have seen ·how my enemies took revenge on me [all their vengeance] ·and made evil plans against me [all their plots against me].

61.verse: LORD, you ·have heard [hear] their ·insults [scorn] and all their ·evil plans [plots] against me.

62.verse: The ·words [whispers; lips] and ·thoughts [mumblings; murmurs] of ·my enemies [those who rise up against me] are against me all the time.

63.verse: Look! In ·everything they do [their sitting and their rising up] they ·make fun of me with songs [sing mocking songs; Ps. 69:7–12].

64.verse: Pay them back, LORD, ·for what they have done [according to the acts of their hands].

65.verse: Make them ·stubborn [insolent of heart], and put your curse on them.

66.verse: ·Chase [Pursue] them in anger, LORD, and destroy them from under ·your [the LORD’s] heavens.

1.verse: The Attack on Jerusalem - See how the gold has ·lost its shine [lost its luster; become dim/dark], how the pure gold has ·dulled [changed]! The stones of the ·Temple [Holy Place] are scattered at ·every street corner [the top of every street].

2.verse: The precious ·people [children; sons] of ·Jerusalem [Zion; the location of the Temple] were ·more valuable than [worth their weight in] gold, but now they are thought of as clay jars ·made by [the work of] the hands of a potter.

3.verse: Even ·wild dogs [jackals] ·give their milk [prepare the breast] to ·feed [suckle; nurse] their young, but [the daughter of] my people are ·cruel [violent] like ostriches in the ·desert [wilderness; Job 39:14–16].

4.verse: The ·babies [nurslings] are so thirsty their tongues stick to ·the roofs of their mouths [their palates]. Children ·beg [ask] for bread, but no one ·gives [offers] them any.

5.verse: Those who once ate ·fine foods [delicacies; the food of the rich; Prov. 23:3, 6] are ·now starving [desolate] in the streets. People who ·grew up [were nurtured] ·wearing nice clothes [in purple/or crimson; expensive clothes often associated with royalty] now ·pick through [cling to] ·trash piles [ash heaps; 1 Sam. 2:8; Job 2:8; Ps. 113:7].

6.verse: ·My people have been punished more than Sodom was [The iniquity/or punishment of the daughter of my people is greater than the sin/or punishment of Sodom]. ·Sodom […which] was ·destroyed [overturned] suddenly, and no hands ·reached out to help her [or were wrung; Gen. 19; Deut. 29:23; Is. 1:9–10; Jer. 23:14; Ezek. 16:46–56; Matt. 10:15; Jude 7; Rev. 11:8].

7.verse: ·Our [or Her] princes were purer than snow, and whiter than milk. Their bodies were redder than ·rubies [or coral]; they looked like ·sapphires [lapis lazuli].

8.verse: But now ·they [their faces] are blacker than coal, and no one recognizes them in the streets. Their skin ·hangs [or shrivels] on their bones; it is as dry as wood.

9.verse: Those who were ·killed [pierced] ·in the war [by the sword] were better off than those ·killed [pierced] by ·hunger [famine]. They ·starve in pain and die [drain/waste away], ·because there is no food from the field [deprived of the produce of the field; Jer. 11:22; 14:12–18].

10.verse: With their own hands ·kind [compassionate] women ·cook [boil] their own children. They became food when ·my [the daughter of my] people were ·destroyed [fractured; broken; Deut. 28:56–57].

11.verse: The LORD turned loose all of his anger; he poured out his ·strong [hot] anger. He set fire to ·Jerusalem [Zion; the location of the Temple; Ps. 74:4–7], ·burning it down to the [consuming its] foundations.

12.verse: Kings of the earth and ·people [the inhabitants] of the world could not believe that enemies and foes could enter the gates of Jerusalem [since God had made his presence known there; Ps. 48:1–2].

13.verse: It happened because her prophets sinned and her priests did evil [Jer. 1:17–19; 2:7–8, 26; 4:9; 13:12–14]. They ·killed [poured out blood] in ·the city [its midst] ·those who did what was right [the righteous].

14.verse: They wandered in the streets as if they were blind. They were ·dirty [defiled; in a ritual sense] with blood [as if covered with menstrual blood; Lev. 15], so no one ·would [was able to] touch their clothes.

15.verse: “·Go away [Turn aside]! ·You are unclean [Unclean!; in a ritual sense],” people shouted at them. “·Get away [Turn aside]! ·Get away [Turn aside]! Don’t touch us!” So they ran away and wandered. Even the other nations said, “Don’t stay here.”

16.verse: The LORD himself ·scattered [dispersed] them and did not ·look after [regard] them anymore. No one respects the priests or ·honors [has favor for] the elders.

17.verse: Also, our eyes ·grew tired [failed], looking for help ·that never came [in vain; without purpose; 2:11; Ps. 69:3; 119:82, 123]. We kept watch ·from our towers [or eagerly] for a nation ·to save us [that could not save us/give us victory; Judah had hoped that Egypt would rescue them from Babylon; Jer. 2:18, 36].

18.verse: ·Our enemies [They] ·hunted [dogged] ·us [our steps], so we could not even walk in the ·streets [public areas]. Our end is near. Our ·time [days] ·is [fill] up. Our end has come.

19.verse: Those who ·chased [pursued] us were faster than eagles in the ·sky [heavens]. They ·ran [chased] us into the mountains and ambushed us in the ·desert [wilderness].

20.verse: The LORD’s ·appointed king [anointed; Judah’s king], ·who was our very breath [the breath of our life/nostrils], was caught in their traps [2 Kin. 25:5–7]. We had said about him, “We will ·be protected by him [live in his shadow/shade] among the nations.”

21.verse: Be happy and ·glad [rejoice], ·people [daughter] of Edom, you who live in the land of Uz [city in Edom; Job 1:1; Jer. 25:20]. The cup [of God’s judgment] will ·come [pass] to you; then you will get drunk and go naked [Jer. 25:15–38; 49:12–13].

22.verse: Your ·punishment [or iniquity] is complete, ·Jerusalem [daughter of Zion; the location of the Temple]. He will not send you into ·captivity again [exile]. But the LORD will punish the ·sins [iniquity] of Edom; he will ·uncover [expose] your ·evil [sin].

1.verse: A Prayer to the Lord - Remember, LORD, what happened to us [a call to God for help and revenge]. Look and see our ·disgrace [scorn].

2.verse: Our ·land [inheritance] has been turned over to strangers; our houses have been given to foreigners.

3.verse: We are like orphans with no father; our mothers are like widows [defenseless and vulnerable].

4.verse: We have to buy the water we drink; ·we must pay for the firewood [our wood comes with a price].

5.verse: ·Those who chase after us want to catch us [We are pursued] by the neck. We are ·tired [exhausted] and find no rest.

6.verse: We ·made an agreement with [gave a hand to] Egypt and with Assyria to get enough food [Is. 28:1—33:24; Jer. 2:35].

7.verse: Our ·ancestors [fathers] sinned against you, but they are ·gone [no more]; now we ·suffer because of their sins [bear their iniquity].

8.verse: ·Slaves [Servants] ·have become our rulers [rule over us; Prov. 19:10; 30:21–22; Eccl. 10:5–7; Is. 24:2], and no one can ·save us from them [tear them off us].

9.verse: We risk our lives to get our ·food [bread]; ·we face death in the desert [because of the sword in the wilderness; fields were outside the walls of the city where the enemy camped].

10.verse: Our skin is ·hot [or black] like an oven; ·we burn with [from the heat/fever of] ·starvation [famine].

11.verse: ·The enemy [They] ·abused [violated; raped] the women ·of Jerusalem [in Zion; the location of the Temple] and the ·girls [virgins] in the ·cities [towns] of Judah.

12.verse: Princes were hung by the hands; they did not respect our ·elders [or old men].

13.verse: The young men ·ground grain at the mill [are forced to grind], and boys stumbled under loads of wood.

14.verse: The ·elders [or old men] ·no longer sit at the city [have left the] gates [the center of government and business]; the young men no longer sing.

15.verse: ·We have no more joy in [Joy has left] our hearts; our dancing has turned to ·sadness [mourning].

16.verse: The crown has fallen from our head. ·How terrible it is [Woe to us] because we sinned.

17.verse: Because of this ·we are afraid [our hearts are sick], and now our eyes ·are dim [grow dark; Ps. 69:23].

18.verse: Mount Zion [Jerusalem] is ·empty [desolate], and ·wild dogs [jackals] wander around it [Jer. 9:11; 10:22].

19.verse: But you ·rule [sit; as king] forever, LORD. ·You will be King [Your throne] ·from now on [from generation to generation].

20.verse: Why have you forgotten us for so long? Have you ·left [abandoned; forsaken] us ·forever [for length of days]?

21.verse: Bring us back to you, LORD, and we will ·return [be restored]. ·Make [Renew] our days as they were before,

22.verse: or have you completely rejected us? Are you so angry with us?
